questions.text: In the Enneking classification for musculoskeletal tumours, a high-grade malignant lesion without metastasis is classified as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
High-grade malignant tumours are labelled as G2, and the absence of metastasis is denoted by M0 in Enneking staging.

  • The Enneking system stages bone tumours based on:
    • G (Grade): Histological aggressiveness
    • T (Site): Tumour location - intracompartmental (T1) or extracompartmental (T2)
    • M (Metastasis): M0 (no metastasis), M1 (present)
  • For high-grade malignant lesions:
    • G2 = High-grade malignancy
    • T1 = Still within the compartment (intracompartmental)
    • M0 = No metastasis
  • Hence, G2 T1 M0 corresponds to a Stage IIA tumour.

Explanation of other options:

G1 T1 M0 (Option A): Represents a low-grade intracompartmental tumour (Stage IA)

G2 T2 M1 (Option C): Represents high-grade, extra-compartmental tumours with metastasis (Stage III)

G1 T0 M0 (Option D): T0 is not used for malignant lesions; it refers to benign tumors

Key Takeaway:
Enneking system categorises tumours into grades and stages, guiding surgical planning and prognosis—G2 T1 M0 = Stage IIA.

questions.text: Which tumour is the commonest true benign tumour of the bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoid osteoma is the most common true benign bone tumour, characterised by a radiolucent nidus surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.

  • Osteoid osteoma is a true benign tumour (not a developmental anomaly like osteochondroma).
  • It typically affects adolescents and young adults (age 5-25).
  • Most commonly affects the diaphysis of long bones, especially the tibia and posterior vertebral elements.
  • Presents with nocturnal pain relieved by salicylates, due to prostaglandin production.
  • X-ray shows a radiolucent nidus (<1 cm) surrounded by sclerosis.
  • Treatment: Surgical excision of the nidus or CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Explanation of other options:

Osteochondroma (Option A): Most common benign bone tumour-like lesion, not a true neoplasm; it's a cartilage-capped bony projection (exostosis).

Osteoblastoma (Option B): Rare, larger than osteoid osteoma, occurs in spine/jaw; not the most common.

Enchondroma (Option C): Cartilage-forming tumour, usually seen in small bones of hands and feet; not the most common overall.

Key Takeaway:
Osteoid osteoma is the most common true benign bone tumour, unlike osteochondroma, which is a developmental anomaly.

choices.text: Generally affects the diaphysis of long bones
The commonest bone affected is the femur

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about osteoid osteoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone-forming tumour and is not a premalignant condition.

  • The most common true benign tumour of bone
  • Typically arises in 2nd-3rd decades, males > females
  • Affects diaphysis of long bones (esp. femur), also spine (posterior elements)(Option A, B ruled out)
  • Presents with nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs
  • Radiology: Radiolucent nidus (<1 cm) surrounded by dense sclerosis(Option C ruled out)
  • Treatment: NSAIDs, burr down technique, or radiofrequency ablation

Key Takeaways:
Osteoid osteoma is benign, painful at night, relieved by NSAIDs, and not premalignant.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressive pain and swelling over the lower thigh. X-ray shows a metaphyseal lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction. Based on the radiographic finding of radiating spicules extending into soft tissue (shown), what is the most likely explanation for this pattern?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The sunray (sunburst) appearance is caused by rapid periosteal elevation and ossification along Sharpey's fibres due to aggressive periosteal reaction.

  • It is an aggressive radiological feature seen in high-grade tumours like conventional osteosarcoma.
  • Other radiological signs in osteosarcoma include Codman's triangle (subperiosteal new bone).
  • Sunray pattern is typically associated with rapid tumour growth and cortical breakthrough.
  • Sharpey's fibres are involved in anchoring periosteum to bone; their calcification gives the radiating appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Bone destruction (Option A): Leads to a permeative appearance, not sunray spicules.

Vascular calcification (Option C): Seen in systemic conditions, not linked to Sharpey's fibres.

Bone hypertrophy (Option D): Uniform bone enlargement, not associated with periosteal spicules.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sunray appearance = periosteal reaction + Sharpey's fibre calcification.
  • Strong radiologic clue for aggressive bone tumours like osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumours arises primarily in the epiphysis of long bones?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Chondroblastoma is one of the few bone tumours that arise primarily in the epiphysis of long bones, most commonly in adolescents.

  • It is a benign cartilaginous tumour found in the epiphysis of the proximal humerus, femur, or tibia.
  • Presents with joint pain, localised tenderness, and occasional joint restriction.
  • Radiologically, it appears as a well-defined, lytic lesion in the epiphysis, often without calcification.
  • Biopsy confirms the diagnosis by showing immature cartilage cells (chondroblasts).

Explanation of other options:

Osteoid osteoma (Option A): Arises in the cortex of the diaphysis or metaphysis, not the epiphysis.

Adamantinoma (Option B): A rare tumour typically seen in the tibial diaphysis, not epiphyseal.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): Commonly occurs in the metaphysis, especially around the knee; rarely epiphyseal.

Key Takeaway:
Chondroblastoma is a classic epiphyseal tumour in young individuals and should be differentiated from other metaphyseal or diaphyseal lesions.

questions.text: An intramedullary tumour occurring in the lower metaphysis of the tibia in a 15-year-old male is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Explanation :
Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumour in adolescents and typically arises from the metaphyseal region of long bones such as the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

  • Most common between 10-20 years of age (first peak of bimodal distribution).
  • Arises in the metaphysis, particularly of rapidly growing bones during adolescence.
  • Appears as an intramedullary lesion expanding into the cortex and soft tissues.
  • Radiographs show mixed lytic and sclerotic features, Codman's triangle, and sunburst appearance.
  • Histologically shows malignant osteoid production.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option A): Typically occurs in the diaphysis or metadiaphysis of long bones and pelvis in younger patients; may appear intramedullary but not classically metaphyseal.

Giant cell tumour (Option C): Occurs after skeletal maturity, usually in the epiphysis extending to the metaphysis; rare before 20 years.

Chondrosarcoma (Option D): Usually affects older adults (>40 years), arises in flat bones or metaphysis of long bones; rare in 15-year-olds.

Key Takeaway:
Osteosarcoma should be the top differential for a metaphyseal intramedullary lesion in an adolescent.

questions.text: Night pains are characteristically seen with:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:
Night pain that is dramatically relieved by NSAIDs is a classical hallmark of osteoid osteoma.

  • A benign bone-forming tumour occurring in young males (5-25 years).
  • Most commonly located in the diaphysis of long bones (e.g. tibia, femur) and posterior spine elements.
  • Pain is worse at night, caused by increased prostaglandin production (COX-mediated) from the nidus.
  • Shows a <1 cm radiolucent nidus with surrounding sclerosis on X-ray.
  • Responds well to salicylates/NSAIDs.

Explanation of other options:

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Causes dull, progressive pain but not specifically night pain or NSAID-responsive pain.

Ewing sarcoma (Option C): Pain is constant, often associated with fever and swelling; night pain is not distinctive.

Fibrous cortical defect (Option D): Typically asymptomatic and found incidentally on X-ray.

Key Takeaway:
Night pain relieved by NSAIDs is highly characteristic of osteoid osteoma, making it an important diagnostic clue.

questions.text: This is the typical appearance of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is an osteoid osteoma. CT is the modality of choice and typically shows a focally lucent nidus within surrounding sclerotic reactive bone. A central sclerotic dot may also be seen.

Osteoid osteoma:

  • Benign bone forming lesions care onsidered to be the most common true benign tumours of the bone
  • Age group - 2nd-3rddecades
  • Male : female = 3 : 1
  • Lower extremity, long bones, Posterior elements spine, Diaphyseal/metaphyseal
  • Pain - worse at night
  • XRAY - Cortical radiolucent nidus <1.5 cm with marked cortical thickening
  • High levels of cyclooxygenases and prostaglandins in the lesion
  • Frequently responds to NSAIDs
  • HISTOLOGY - Trabeculae surrounded by loose fibrovascular tissue
  • TREATMENT - NSAIDs, Burr down technique, Radiofrequency ablation.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoblastoma (Option B): Larger than 2 cm, often involves the spine, less cortical thickening, and dull pain.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): Malignant metaphyseal tumour with sunburst periosteal reaction and Codman triangle.

Stress fracture (Option D): Linear sclerosis withouta  discrete nidus, typically seen in athletes or overuse.

Key Takeaway:
CT showing a small radiolucent nidus with dense reactive bone is diagnostic of osteoid osteoma.

questions.text: Identify the tumour shown in the X-ray image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • GCT The X-ray depicts the diagnostic Soap bubble appearance of a Giant cell tumour, which is one of the commonest tumours to be seen in the distal end of the radius.
  • However, the commonest sites for the GCT per se are: Distal femur, Proximal tibia, Distal radius.

Giant cell tumour:

  • AGE (YR):20-40 Slight female predominance
  • SITE:Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius
  • PRESENTATION:Pain, Pathologic fracture(10%-30%), Eggshell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING:

  • Eccentrically located in the epiphysis
  • Purely radiolucent(no matrix formation), Soap bubble appearance
  • Usually, no rim of reactive bone
  • Abuts subchondral bone
  • May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension
  • Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:

  • Multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells
  • Nuclei of mononuclear cells are identical to nuclei of giant cells

TREATMENT:

  • Extended curettage, Resection if residual bone stock is inadequate
  • Consider radiation for spinal/sacral tumours, Resection of pulmonary metastases

Explanation of other options:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option A): Lytic expansile lesion in metaphysis with fluid-fluid levels on imaging, not typically epiphyseal.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Malignant metaphyseal tumour with sunburst periosteal reaction, Codman triangle-not soap-bubble.

Simple bone cyst (Option D): Central metaphyseal lesion in children, usually the humerus or femur, with the fallen fragment sign, not eccentric or epiphyseal.

Key Takeaway:
A soap-bubble appearance in the epiphysis of the distal radius in a young adult points toward a giant cell tumour.

questions.text: The most common malignancy that metastasises to the spine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breast cancer is the most frequent primary malignancy metastasising to the spine, especially in females.

  • Metastatic bone disease is the most common malignant condition affecting the skeleton.
  • The vertebral column is the most frequent site for skeletal metastases due to its rich vascular supply (Batson's venous plexus).
  • Metastases to the spine are usually osteolytic, except prostate (osteoblastic).
  • Common sources by gender:
    • Females: Breast > Lung > Thyroid
    • Males: Prostate > Lung > Kidney
  • Overall most common: Breast carcinoma.
  • Symptoms include persistent back pain, pathological fractures, and neurological deficits due to spinal cord compression.
  • Diagnosis involves MRI (best for marrow lesions), CT, and skeletal survey.

Important Points Table:

Explanation of other options:

Lung (Option A): Commonly metastasises but ranks lower than breast in females.

Prostate (Option B): Most common in males, but not overall. Metastases are typically osteoblastic.

Thyroid (Option D): Can metastasise to the spine, but is less common overall.

Key Takeaway:
Breast carcinoma is the most common malignancy to metastasise to the spine overall, particularly in women.

questions.text: Which of the following is a GCT variant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is considered a GCT variant due to the presence of abundant multinucleated giant cells on histology.

  • GCT variants are lesions that histologically mimic true GCT due to the presence of numerous multinucleated giant cells.
  • These lesions are not true neoplasms of the GCT family but resemble them under microscopy.
  • The importance lies in accurate diagnosis and appropriate management, as some of these may behave differently clinically.
  • ABC is a benign, expansile, blood-filled lesion that can occur de novo or secondarily within another tumour like GCT.
  • Microscopically, ABC shows blood-filled spaces lined by fibroblasts, histiocytes, and giant cells.

Explanation of other options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A): It shows giant cells but is primarily a cartilaginous tumour, not a true GCT variant.

Osteosarcoma with giant cells (Option C): It's a malignant tumour with occasional giant cells but not a benign GCT variant.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option D): A fibrous lesion with some giant cells but not classified as a direct GCT variant on its own.

Key Takeaway:
GCT variants are benign bone lesions that mimic GCT histologically; ABC is one of the most common among them.

choices.text: En bloc excision with structural allograft reconstruction
En bloc excision with wrist fusion using vascularized fibular autograft
Curettage, application of liquid nitrogen and polymethylmethacrylate

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with swelling and pain in the right wrist. The symptoms have progressed over the last 6 months, and she has noted a decreased range of motion of the wrist joint. Figures A and B show the histology. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For GCT with preserved cortex and joint, extended curettage with adjuvants like liquid nitrogen and PMMA is preferred.

  • Giant Cell Tumour (GCT) of bone is a locally aggressive benign tumour, often involving epiphyseal regions in young adults.
  • The distal radius is among the common sites of GCT (after the distal femur and proximal tibia).
  • Histology shows multinucleated giant cells dispersed in a background of mononuclear stromal cells.
  • In cases with intact cortex and articular surface, extensive curettage with adjuvants (liquid nitrogen, phenol, PMMA) is the treatment of choice.
  • Polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) acts via thermal necrosis of residual cells and helps detect recurrence radiographically.
  • Radiation is reserved for unresectable spinal lesions; en bloc excision with reconstruction is considered if the cortex or joint is destroyed.

Explanation of other options:

Radiation (Option A): Used only when surgery is not feasible (e.g., sacral/spinal tumours).

En bloc excision with allograft (Option B): Reserved for extensive lesions with joint destruction.

En bloc with fibular graft (Option C): Used in more destructive or recurrent GCT of the distal radius.

Key Takeaway:
For GCT with preserved bone and joint, curettage with adjuvant therapy and bone cement (PMMA) offers joint preservation and local control.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female reports lateral knee pain and slight fullness. She underwent a bone scan, which showed increased activity isolated to the proximal fibula. Radiographs and histology are shown in Figures A and B. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A lytic lesion in the epiphyseometaphyseal region with uniform giant cells is characteristic of giant cell tumour (GCT).

  • Giant cell tumour (GCT) is a benign but locally aggressive lesion that typically occurs in adults aged 20-40 years, with a slight female preponderance.
  • Commonly affects epiphyseometaphyseal regions of long bones-most frequently around the knee, including distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal fibula.
  • Radiology: Lytic, expansile lesion abutting the subchondral bone without a rim of sclerosis.
  • Histology: Numerous multinucleated giant cells are dispersed in a background of mononuclear stromal cells-a hallmark of GCT.
  • Clinical features: Pain, swelling, and occasionally pathological fractures.
  • Management: Extended curettage with adjuvants like PMMA or bone grafting. Recurrence and rare malignant transformation are known.

Explanation of other options:

Parosteal osteosarcoma (Option A): Juxtacortical tumour with dense mineralisation; typically metaphyseal and slow-growing, unlike the lytic, intramedullary lesion here.

Eosinophilic granuloma (Option B): A pediatric lesion involving flat bones or skull; rarely affects long bone epiphysis in adults.

Multiple myeloma (Option C): Common in the elderly, presents with multiple punched-out lesions; fibula is a rare site, and histology shows plasma cells, not giant cells.

Key Takeaway:
GCT typically presents as an epiphyseal lytic lesion in young adults with multinucleated giant cells and is treated with extended curettage.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with epiphyseal bone tumour shows lytic lesion with chicken-wire calcification.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chicken-wire calcification in an epiphyseal lytic lesion is pathognomonic for chondroblastoma.

  • Chondroblastoma, also known as Codman tumour, is a benign cartilage-forming tumour typically seen in the second to third decade of life.
  • It has a predilection for the epiphysis of long bones, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • Radiological features: Well-defined epiphyseal lytic lesion, often with a sclerotic rim and patchy (mottled) calcifications.
  • Histopathology: Composed of polyhedral chondroblasts, chondroid matrix, and scattered giant cells.
  • Most characteristic feature: Chicken-wire calcification, i.e., thin lace-like calcium deposits surrounding individual cells.
  • Treatment: Extended curettage with bone grafting.

Explanation of other options:

Giant cell tumour (Option A): Typically occurs in skeletally mature individuals, eccentric lesion abutting subchondral bone, lacks chicken-wire calcification.

Osteoblastoma (Option B): Affects metaphyseal or diaphyseal regions, not epiphysis; produces osteoid, not chondroid matrix.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option D): Highly malignant, diaphyseal tumour with "onion-skin" periosteal reaction, no cartilage or calcification features.

Key Takeaway:
Chondroblastoma should be suspected in a young adult with an epiphyseal lytic lesion and chicken-wire calcification.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with swelling in the mid-thigh region. On examination, femoral thickening was found with Codman's triangle. On aspiration, greyish white liquid was aspirated that showed atypical round cells with MIC-2 positivity. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MIC-2 positivity with small round blue cells and Codman's triangle in a diaphyseal lesion is classic for Ewing's sarcoma.

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant tumour seen in children and adolescents, most commonly between 10-20 years.
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur, is the most frequent site.
  • Radiological hallmark is onion-skin (laminated) periosteal reaction; Codman's triangle can also be present.
  • Grossly, tumour tissue is grey-white, soft, and often mistaken for pus, which is consistent with the aspirated fluid in this case.
  • Histologically composed of uniform small round cells arranged in sheets with pseudo-rosettes.
  • Cells show MIC-2 (CD99) positivity and t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation in ~85% cases.
  • May present with fever and systemic symptoms, mimicking osteomyelitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Arises from metaphysis, not diaphysis; features malignant osteoid with sunburst or Codman's triangle. MIC-2 negative.

Tubercular Osteomyelitis (Option C): Chronic presentation, cold abscess, no MIC-2 positivity; histology shows granulomas, not round cells.

Pyogenic Osteomyelitis (Option D): Presents with fever, pain, and pus but lacks MIC-2 expression and small round blue cells.

Key Takeaway:

Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant diaphyseal tumour in children characterised by MIC-2 positivity and onion-skin or Codman's periosteal reaction.

questions.text: Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level at the time of diagnosis is considered a poor prognostic marker for which of the following bone tumours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Raised LDH level indicates tumour burden and systemic involvement in Ewing's sarcoma, marking it as a poor prognostic factor.

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant small round cell tumour affecting mainly the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents.
  • Prognosis is influenced by both clinical and biochemical factors.
  • Poor prognostic indicators include:
    • Elevated LDH, ESR, and WBC count
    • Tumor size > 8 cm
    • Central/proximal tumour location
    • Metastasis at diagnosis (especially lung and bone)
    • Poor response to chemotherapy
    • Male gender and age > 17 years
    • Early recurrence within 1 year
  • LDH elevation reflects tumour cell turnover and is associated with aggressive disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Elevated alkaline phosphatase is more relevant; LDH is not a key prognostic marker.

Osteoid osteoma (Option B): Benign tumour, not associated with LDH changes.

Giant cell tumour (Option C): May recur locally, but LDH levels do not affect prognosis.

Key Takeaway:

In Ewing's sarcoma, elevated LDH is a strong marker of tumour aggressiveness and indicates a worse prognosis.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old cross-country runner complains of vague shin pain. A radiograph of the tibia is seen in Figure A.

A biopsy is performed and is shown in Figure B.

Which of the following chromosomal translocations is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ewing's sarcoma is characteristically associated with a t(11;22) translocation forming the EWS-FLI1 fusion gene.

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant small round cell tumour that arises from the diaphysis of long bones, commonly in the second decade.
  • A common radiologic feature is onion-skin periosteal reaction due to layered new bone formation.
  • Biopsy typically shows sheets of uniform small round cells with round nuclei and scant cytoplasm.
  • The tumour exhibits strong immunoreactivity for MIC-2 (CD99) and periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positivity.
  • Cytogenetic hallmark:
    • t(11;22)(q24;q12) translocation resulting in the EWS-FLI1 fusion gene, critical for diagnosis.
  • Other features:
    • Often confused clinically with osteomyelitis due to fever and inflammatory signs.
    • May metastasise early to the lungs and bones.
    • Treated with multiagent chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiotherapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

t(10;20) (Option A): No known association with common bone tumours. Synovial sarcoma is associated

t(X;18) (Option C): Seen in synovial sarcoma, not Ewing's.

t(9;22) (Option D): Found in chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) and extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma.

Key Takeaway:

The characteristic cytogenetic translocation in Ewing's sarcoma is t(11;22), forming the oncogenic EWS-FLI1 fusion gene.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl comes to the office with increasing thigh pain, mostly at night. Radiograph and biopsy specimen are shown in Figures A and B. The patient's WBC and ESR are both elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ewing's sarcoma is the most likely diagnosis given the age, site (diaphysis), imaging findings, and histopathology showing sheets of small round blue cells.

  • Most common in children and adolescents aged 10-20 years
  • Arises from the diaphysis of long bones, particularly the femur and tibia
  • Radiograph typically shows a lytic lesion with "onion-skin" periosteal reaction
  • Histology shows uniform round blue cells forming pseudo-rosettes
  • Often presents with systemic features like fever, elevated WBC, and raised ESR, which may mimic osteomyelitis
  • Very chemo- and radio-sensitive
  • Bone-to-bone metastasis is common; hence, a bone scan is essential
  • Treatment includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Radiotherapy is reserved for unresectable tumours or poor surgical candidates
  • MIC-2 (CD99) positivity and t(11;22) translocation are diagnostic markers

Explanation of other options:

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Typically metaphyseal, with sunburst appearance and Codman triangle; occurs in older adolescents

Osteomyelitis (Option C): Presents with fever and pain but lacks onion-skin reaction, and histology shows neutrophilic infiltrate, not small round cells

Giant cell tumour (Option D): Occurs after skeletal maturity, usually epiphyseal in location, and is not seen in young children

Key Takeaway:
Ewing's sarcoma should be suspected in diaphyseal lesions with onion-skin appearance, systemic signs, and biopsy showing small round blue cells in children.

questions.text: The most frequent benign bone tumour of the hand is -
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Enchondroma is the most common benign bone tumour of the hand, typically involving the small tubular bones.

  • It is an intramedullary tumour composed of mature hyaline cartilage
  • Most often affects the phalanges and metacarpals, followed bythe femur and humerus
  • Usually asymptomatic and found incidentally
  • Radiographs show central, well-defined, lobulated lesions with a thin sclerotic rim and characteristic "popcorn" or "ring-like" calcifications
  • Malignant transformation is rare but may occur in syndromic cases like Ollier's disease or Maffucci syndrome
  • Treatment is usually not required unless there is pain or a pathological fracture

Related Important Points and Concepts:

Explanation of other options:

Osteochondroma (Option B): Most common benign bone tumour overall, but occurs at metaphyseal regions of long bones, not typically in the hand

Chondrosarcoma (Option C): Malignant cartilage tumour; occurs in older adults and typically in the pelvis or femur

Glomus tumour (Option D): Painful soft tissue tumour under fingernails, not a primary bone tumour

Key Takeaway:
Enchondroma is the most common benign tumour of the bones of the hand, usually affecting phalanges and metacarpals.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of adamantinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adamantinoma is a rare, low-grade malignant tumour most commonly arising from the diaphysis of the tibia, accounting for up to 85% of cases involving long bones.

  • Occurs in young adults between 20-40 years of age
  • Presents as a gradually enlarging, painless swelling
  • Tibia > Fibula are the most common skeletal sites
  • X-ray shows a honeycomb or soap-bubble appearance with well-defined loculated lesions in the diaphysis
  • Histologically, the tumour shows epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma
  • It is slow-growing with low metastatic potential, though pulmonary metastasis can occur
  • Treatment is by wide resection or amputation, depending on the extent

Explanation of other options:

Mandible near symphysis menti (Option A): Site associated with ameloblastoma, a benign odontogenic tumour, not adamantinoma

Mandible near molar tooth (Option B): Also related to ameloblastoma, not long bone adamantinoma

Hard palate (Option D): Not a site for adamantinoma; may be involved in minor salivary gland tumours

Key Takeaway:
Adamantinoma is a rare, low-grade malignant tumour that most commonly arises in the diaphysis of the tibia in young adults.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a lesion in the upper tibia. X-ray shows a radiolucent area with Codman's triangle and Sunray appearance.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classical sunray appearance with Codman's triangle in a lesion located at the metaphyseal region (upper tibia) is highly characteristic of osteosarcoma.

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumour in children and adolescents
  • It typically arises from the metaphysis of long bones, especially:
    • Distal femur
    • Proximal tibia
    • Proximal humerus
  • Radiological features include:
    • Codman's triangle: Lifting of periosteum due to aggressive growth
    • Sunburst or sunray appearance: Perpendicular spicules of bone from tumour ossification
  • Occurs predominantly between 10-20 years of age
  • Pain, swelling, and limited joint motion are common presentations

Explanation of other options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option A): Usually diaphyseal in location; may show onion-skin appearance, not classical sunray

Osteoid osteoma (Option C): Small benign lesion with central nidus and reactive sclerosis, not associated with Codman's triangle

Chondrosarcoma (Option D): Occurs in adults, primarily in the pelvis or long bone metaphysis/diaphysis, rare in children

Key Takeaway:
Osteosarcoma commonly arises in the metaphyseal region of long bones in children and shows classical radiological signs like Codman's triangle and sunburst appearance.

questions.text: 10-year-old boy injured his right shoulder playing lacrosse. He denies previous shoulder pain or injury. Radiographs of the shoulder show a non-displaced pathologic fracture through a unicameral bone cyst(UBC). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Initial non-operative management with sling support is appropriate for a non-displaced pathological fracture through a unicameral bone cyst in a child.

  • This patient presents with a non-displaced pathologic fracture through a unicameral bone cyst(UBC) of the right proximal humerus.
  • The best next step would be a sling for comfort.
  • Unicameral bone cysts are non-neoplastic, serous fluid-filled bone lesions that are thought to result from the temporary failure of medullary bone formation near the physis.
  • They are most commonly located in the proximal humerus.
  • A pathologic fracture may be the first known presentation of the cyst, as these lesions are usually asymptomatic.
  • These benign lesions occur almost exclusively in children and adolescents(up to 85% of cases) with a reported peak between ages 3 and 14 years.
  • Primary differential diagnoses for UBC include aneurysmal bone cyst(ABC), fibrous dysplasia, enchondroma and intraosseous ganglia.
  • In patients with a pathologic fracture of the upper extremity associated with a UBC, initial nonsurgical treatment with immobilisation for 4 to 6 weeks is appropriate.

Explanation of other options:

Urgent biopsy (Option A): Not indicated unless there are suspicious features or soft tissue extension.

CT scan of arm (Option B): Not needed initially for a classical radiographic UBC with a simple fracture

Open reduction and plate fixation (Option D): Not required unless the fracture is displaced or complicated.

Key Takeaway:
Sling support is the first-line treatment for a non-displaced fracture through a unicameral bone cyst in children.

questions.text: All of the following are benign tumours except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chordoma is a rare, slow-growing but malignant tumour, most commonly involving the sacrum and clivus.
It arises from notochordal remnants and is not a benign tumour, unlike the other listed options.

  • Chondroma, Osteochondroma, and Enchondroma are all benign cartilaginous tumours.
  • Chordomas, although slow-growing, are locally aggressive, infiltrative, and prone to recurrence and metastasis.
  • Histologically, chordomas show physaliphorous (bubble-like) cells, which is characteristic.

Explanation of other options:

Chondroma (Option A): Benign tumour composed of mature cartilage, often asymptomatic.

Osteochondroma (Option B): Most common benign tumour, arises fromthe  metaphysis with a cartilage cap.

Enchondroma (Option D): Intramedullary benign cartilage tumour, frequently seen in the hand bones.

Key Takeaway:
Chordoma is a malignant tumour, while the others listed are benign cartilaginous tumours.
